title: Data export
comment: Data can be exported in CSV format via the "Share" icon to e.g. an email (possibly useful) or Facebook (not useful), but not to a file. Note that many sensor apps can't log or export at all.

The Share function on Android works as a generic pipe. One app says "I wan't to share data of this kind", then the OS will look for apps that can receive that kind of data. In other words, you need to install an app that accepts text and is able to write it to a file (e.g. a text editor). Neither E-Mail nor Facebook are hardwired to SensorReadout.

title: Amazing App
comment: I didn't even realize my phone could do any of this. I was amazed by the accuracy. I moved the magnetic field sensor closer to my computer screen and it was extremely precise in detecting the change.

Works great, awesome for testing sensors if you are technically minded.	Used this app to diagnose weird behavior in the compass function on my Galaxy Nexus. The live graphs of the different sensor outputs let me diagnose exactly which sensor (the magnetometer) and which part of it (the x-axis sensor) was causing the problems. I then used it to do a more careful than usual figure-8 wave calibration while viewing the magnetometer output, and could see exactly when I had done it enough to make the x-axis magnetometer sensor accurate enough again.  You do need to have a good spatial sense of axis orientations and be OK with reading graphs for the app to be useful. Not really aimed at the casual user, but very useful for the technically minded, whether you want to diagnose a sensor problem or just have fun viewing live sensor output.
